channel.title: Reinventing Your Life (Book) on Personal Knowledge Wiki
channel.description: Recent content in Reinventing Your Life (Book) on Personal Knowledge Wiki

item.title: Chapter 10: I can't make it on my own: The Dependence Lifetrap
item.description: Margaret: Twenty-eight years old, feels trapped in her marriage to an abusive husband. When Margaret first walks into our office there is a frightened look in her eyes. It raises a protective impulse in us and we move to take care of her. When we tell her she seems frightened, she tells us that she does not even like to think about her problems, let alone talk about them.

item.title: Chapter 1: Lifetraps
item.description: Are you repeatedly drawn into relationships with people who are cold to you? Do you feel that even the people closest to you do not care or understand enough about you? Do you feel that you are at your core somehow defective, that no one who truly knows you could possibly love and accept you? Do you put the needs of others above your own, so your needs never get metâ€”and so you do not even know what your real needs are?

item.title: Chapter 2: Which lifetraps do you have?
item.description: In this chapter, we will help you identify which lifetraps seem most pertinent to your life. Rate each of the next twenty-two statements in terms of how true each is of you on this six-point scale. Scoring Key: Completely untrue of me Mostly untrue of me Slightly more true than untrue of me Moderately true of me Mostly true of me Describes me perfectly First, rate how true the statement was of you as a child.

item.title: Chapter 8: I'll Never Get The Love I Need, The Emotional Deprivation Lifetrap
item.description: [2022-03-14 Mon 17:36] Jed: Thirty-nine years old. Women always disappoint him emotionally. Two things struck us about Jed as he walked into our office for the first time. One was how handsome he looked, and the other was how cold. There was a remote quality to him that was difficult to pierce in therapy. But in that first session he sat down and told us why he was there.

item.title: Chapter 9: I Don't Fit In, The Social Exclusion Lifetrap
item.description: [2022-03-16 Wed 13:31] Debra: Twenty-five years old. She feels anxious and inferior in social situations. In our first session, Debra tells us that she is unhappy with her social life. Ever since college ended, she has had trouble meeting people. DEBRA: I haven’t had a date in seven months. I haven’t really met anybody who wants to date me. THERAPIST: Where do you usually meet people?

item.title: How Lifetraps Change
item.description: Steps: Label and Identify your Lifetraps Subjugation Defectiveness Failure Social Exclusion Understand the Childhood Origins of Your Lifetrap. Feel the Wounded Child Inside You. The Third Step is to Build a Case Against Your Lifetrap. Disprove its Validity at a Rational Level. Write Letters to the Parent, Sibling, or Peer Who Helped Cause Your Lifetrap. Examine Your Lifetrap Pattern in Careful Detail.

item.title: I'm Worthless: The Defectiveness Lifetrap
item.description: page: 207 Alison: Thirty years old. She feels unworthy of love. Alison looks frightened when she walks into our office. It is obvious she is uncomfortable talking about herself. We try to put her at ease. After a while, we ask her why she has come. She tells us she is depressed. ALISON: I guess I get down on myself a lot. I am always thinking, “Why would anyone want to be with me?

item.title: Preface
item.description: [2022-03-18 Fri 11:43] Why another self-help book? We believe that Reinventing Your Life fills an important gap in the books currently available for self-improvement. There are many excellent self-help books, just as there are many fine therapy approaches. However, most of these are limited. Some books only deal with one specific problem, like codependency, depression, lack of assertiveness, or making poor partner choices. Some deal with many problems, but only use one means of change, like inner-child work, couples exercises, or cognitive-behavioral methods.

item.title: The Failure Lifetrap
item.description: Kathleen: Thirty-eight years old. Considers herself a failure in her professional life. When Kathleen first walks into our office, she has a tense, crestfallen appearance. She tells us that she has considered coming to therapy for quite some time, but has put it off. KATHLEEN: Lately I’ve been feeling really depressed. THERAPIST: How did it start? KATHLEEN: Well, I’ve really been depressed for a long time.
